title: Ezekiel Chapter 42 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 42 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 42 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 42.

questions.question: In which direction did he bring Ezekiel into the utter court according to Ezekiel 42:1?
questions.correctAnswer: North
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:1 states that he brought Ezekiel into the utter court, the way toward the north.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:2, what was the length of the north door?
questions.correctAnswer: 100 cubits
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:2 specifies the length of the north door as one hundred cubits.

questions.question: How many stories were the galleries built in Ezekiel 42:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Three
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:3 mentions that the gallery was against gallery in three stories.

questions.question: What was the breadth of the walk before the chambers as described in Ezekiel 42:4?
questions.correctAnswer: 10 cubits
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:4 describes a walk of ten cubits breadth inward before the chambers.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 42:5, the upper chambers were longer than the lower and middle ones.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:5 states that the upper chambers were shorter, not longer, than the lower and middlemost.

questions.question: Why was the building described as straitened more than the lower and middlemost in Ezekiel 42:6?
options: Because the upper chambers had more pillars
Because they had no pillars like the courts' pillars
Because it was made of stone
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had no pillars like the courts' pillars
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:6 explains the building was straitened because the upper chambers had no pillars like the pillars of the courts.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:7, what was the length of the wall toward the utter court opposite the chambers?
questions.correctAnswer: 50 cubits
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:7 states the length of the wall over against the chambers was fifty cubits.

questions.question: Where was the entry to the chambers located according to Ezekiel 42:9?
questions.correctAnswer: East side
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:9 notes the entry was on the east side as one goes into the chambers from the utter court.

questions.question: The chambers in the thickness of the wall of the court were located toward which direction according to Ezekiel 42:10?
questions.correctAnswer: East
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:10 states that the chambers were in the thickness of the wall of the court toward the east.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 42:13, the north and south chambers before the separate place are for common people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 says these chambers are holy chambers where priests eat the most holy things, not for common people.

questions.question: What are priests instructed to do with their garments when entering the holy chambers according to Ezekiel 42:14?
options: Wear them inside and outside the holy place
Lay them down and put on other garments
Take them off and enter naked
questions.correctAnswer: Lay them down and put on other garments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:14 instructs priests to lay down their ministering garments in the holy place and put on other garments to approach the people's offerings.

questions.question: How many reeds did he measure the east side with according to Ezekiel 42:16?
questions.correctAnswer: 500 reeds
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:16 specifies the east side was measured as five hundred reeds.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 42:20 describes a wall five hundred reeds long and five hundred reeds broad surrounding the area.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:20 confirms the wall was five hundred reeds long and broad round about.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:15, what did he do after measuring the inner house?
options: He brought Ezekiel to the west gate
He brought Ezekiel to the east gate and measured it round about
He measured the height of the chambers
He rested and did not measure anything else
questions.correctAnswer: He brought Ezekiel to the east gate and measured it round about
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:15 states that after finishing the inner house measurements, he brought Ezekiel to the east gate and measured it round about.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ezekiel 42:8: 'For the length of the chambers that were in the utter court was ______ cubits.'
questions.correctAnswer: fifty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:8 states the length of the chambers in the utter court was fifty cubits.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 42 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 42 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with maintaining integrity in their service to God. Based on Ezekiel 42, what biblical truth about holiness and service would you share?
options: Priests must change garments when moving from holy to common duties to maintain holiness.
Priests should work without any distinction between holy and common tasks.
The holy place is open to all without restrictions.
Priests can carry sin offerings outside the holy chambers.
questions.correctAnswer: Priests must change garments when moving from holy to common duties to maintain holiness.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13-14 teaches that priests must lay aside their holy garments when leaving the holy place and put on other garments before approaching the people's offerings, emphasizing maintaining holiness and integrity in service.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 42 demonstrate the importance of order and discipline in our spiritual lives?
options: By describing precise measurements and orderly chambers for the priests’ service.
By allowing priests to serve in any chamber without restriction.
By focusing mainly on the external beauty of the temple.
By instructing that anyone can enter the holy chambers freely.
questions.correctAnswer: By describing precise measurements and orderly chambers for the priests’ service.
questions.explanation: The chapter details exact measurements of chambers, doors, and courts (Ezekiel 42:1-12, 15-20), showing God’s desire for order and discipline in worship and service, which applies to maintaining spiritual discipline in life.

questions.question: A believer wants to develop humility and contentment. What can Ezekiel 42 teach about recognizing God’s design and limits?
options: God’s design includes specific measurements and boundaries, teaching us to respect limits.
We should always seek to expand beyond God’s boundaries.
Boundaries in worship are unimportant and flexible.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s design includes specific measurements and boundaries, teaching us to respect limits.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:16-20 describes the measuring of the temple courts to create separation between holy and common areas, illustrating the importance of respecting God’s boundaries as an expression of humility and contentment.

questions.question: How does the description of the holy chambers in Ezekiel 42 teach about stewardship and careful handling of sacred things?
options: Holy chambers were designated for storing offerings and sacred items, showing careful stewardship.
Sacred items could be stored anywhere in the temple.
Offerings were not important to keep separate.
Priests could take offerings home freely.
questions.correctAnswer: Holy chambers were designated for storing offerings and sacred items, showing careful stewardship.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 explains that holy chambers are where priests lay the most holy things and offerings, teaching us to be faithful stewards of what God entrusts to us in service and life.

questions.question: A church leader is teaching about perseverance through spiritual trials. What lesson about perseverance can be drawn from the detailed measurements and structure in Ezekiel 42?
options: Perseverance involves following God’s detailed plan even when it seems meticulous or difficult.
God’s plans are flexible and don’t require careful adherence.
Perseverance is unnecessary if the work is hard.
One should ignore details and focus on feelings.
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance involves following God’s detailed plan even when it seems meticulous or difficult.
questions.explanation: The chapter’s emphasis on exact measurements and structure (Ezekiel 42:1-20) reflects God’s call to persevere in obedience and faithfulness, even in detailed or challenging aspects of spiritual life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 42, the chambers over against the separate place were unimportant and could be used for any purpose.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 states that the chambers before the separate place are holy chambers for priests to eat and lay the most holy things, indicating their special and important use.

questions.question: True or False: The measurements of the temple’s four sides were all equal, showing God’s desire for symmetry and order in worship.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:16-20 shows that each side was measured at five hundred reeds, demonstrating God’s intentional design for order and balance in the sanctuary.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42, what practical lesson about honesty and integrity in work can be drawn from the detailed measurements of the temple?
options: Precise measurements reflect God’s call to honesty and integrity in all tasks.
Details and measurements are not important in honest work.
Integrity means cutting corners wherever possible.
Work for God is only about big actions, not details.
questions.correctAnswer: Precise measurements reflect God’s call to honesty and integrity in all tasks.
questions.explanation: The methodical measurements and care in building the temple (Ezekiel 42:1-20) highlight the importance of honesty and integrity even in small details, applicable to daily work and service.

questions.question: How does the passage about priests changing garments (Ezekiel 42:14) encourage spiritual discipline in personal devotion?
options: It stresses the need to prepare and approach God with reverence and proper disposition.
It suggests that external actions don’t matter in devotion.
Garments are just symbolic and have no real spiritual meaning.
Priests could wear the same clothes for all duties without change.
questions.correctAnswer: It stresses the need to prepare and approach God with reverence and proper disposition.
questions.explanation: Changing garments before approaching different duties (Ezekiel 42:14) symbolizes spiritual discipline and reverence required in personal devotion and ministry.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their child about obedience and trust in God’s Word. What example from Ezekiel 42 can you share?
options: God’s detailed instructions for the temple show the importance of obeying His Word fully and trusting His design.
Obedience to God’s Word is optional and flexible.
Trusting God means ignoring detailed instructions.
Children should decide what parts of God’s Word to follow.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s detailed instructions for the temple show the importance of obeying His Word fully and trusting His design.
questions.explanation: The chapter’s detail about measurements and chambers (Ezekiel 42:1-20) illustrates the importance of full obedience and trust in God’s revealed plan.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 42 teaches that the chambers in the temple were designed to be ____ cubits long and ____ cubits broad, showing God’s order in worship.
questions.correctAnswer: fifty, fifty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:7 and 42:8 state the chambers were fifty cubits in length and breadth, reflecting God’s precise design.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 42 encourage generosity and stewardship in church life?
options: By assigning specific places for offerings and holy things, emphasizing careful stewardship of God’s gifts.
By allowing priests to use offerings for personal gain.
questions.correctAnswer: By assigning specific places for offerings and holy things, emphasizing careful stewardship of God’s gifts.
questions.explanation: The holy chambers where offerings are kept (Ezekiel 42:13) demonstrate respect and stewardship of God’s gifts, encouraging generosity and responsible church life.

questions.question: What does the three-story gallery structure (Ezekiel 42:3-6) teach about spiritual growth and progression?
options: Spiritual growth involves ascending through stages, with each level building on the last.
Spiritual growth is immediate and without stages.
The structure is only architectural with no spiritual meaning.
Growth means jumping between unrelated levels.
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual growth involves ascending through stages, with each level building on the last.
questions.explanation: The three stories of galleries (Ezekiel 42:3-6) metaphorically suggest progressive spiritual development and discipline in the Christian journey.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to neglect fellowship and service in the church. What does Ezekiel 42 teach about the importance of designated roles and places in church life?
options: God designates specific roles and places for service, showing the value of orderly fellowship and ministry.
Service can be random without order.
Fellowship is optional in spiritual growth.
questions.correctAnswer: God designates specific roles and places for service, showing the value of orderly fellowship and ministry.
questions.explanation: The careful designation of chambers and courts for priests and offerings (Ezekiel 42:1-14) highlights God’s order in church roles and fellowship.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 42’s description of boundaries in the temple help believers deal with temptation?
options: Boundaries separate the holy from the common, teaching believers to set limits to avoid temptation.
Boundaries are unnecessary in spiritual life.
Temptation should be ignored, not avoided.
Believers can cross any boundary without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: Boundaries separate the holy from the common, teaching believers to set limits to avoid temptation.
questions.explanation: The wall separating sanctuary and profane place (Ezekiel 42:20) symbolizes the importance of setting boundaries to resist temptation and preserve holiness.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 42 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 42.

questions.question: What is the specific direction toward which Ezekiel was brought into the utter court as described in Ezekiel 42:1?
questions.correctAnswer: North
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:1 explicitly states that he was brought into the utter court, the way toward the north.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:2, what were the dimensions of the north door before the chambers?
questions.correctAnswer: 100 cubits long and 50 cubits broad
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:2 describes the north door as having a length of an hundred cubits and a breadth of fifty cubits.

questions.question: What architectural feature is described in Ezekiel 42:3 as being "gallery against gallery in three stories"?
options: The pavement of the utter court
questions.correctAnswer: The chambers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:3 mentions galleries against galleries in three stories over against the inner court and pavement of the utter court, referring to the chambers.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:5, how do the upper chambers compare in height to the lower and middlemost parts of the building?
questions.correctAnswer: They are shorter
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:5 clearly states that the upper chambers were shorter because the galleries were higher than these.

questions.question: What is the significance of the absence of pillars in the three stories of chambers as noted in Ezekiel 42:6?
options: The chambers were open to the sky
questions.correctAnswer: The building was more straitened
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:6 explains that because the chambers did not have pillars as the courts did, the building was more straitened from the ground.

questions.question: Where were the chambers located according to Ezekiel 42:10?
options: In the thickness of the wall of the court toward the east
In the middle of the inner court
questions.correctAnswer: In the thickness of the wall of the court toward the east
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:10 specifies that the chambers were in the thickness of the wall of the court toward the east.

questions.question: What purpose do the north and south chambers serve as described in Ezekiel 42:13?
options: Holy chambers where priests eat the most holy things
questions.correctAnswer: Holy chambers where priests eat the most holy things
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 states these chambers are holy chambers where priests that approach the LORD shall eat the most holy things.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:14, what must priests do with their garments when they enter the holy chambers?
options: Lay down the garments they minister in and put on other garments
Change garments only after leaving the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Lay down the garments they minister in and put on other garments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:14 explains that priests must leave their ministering garments in the holy place and put on other garments to approach the things for the people.

questions.question: How long was the east side of the temple complex as measured by the reed according to Ezekiel 42:16?
questions.correctAnswer: 500 reeds
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:16 states that the east side was measured as five hundred reeds with the measuring reed.

questions.question: What is the total measurement of the temple area as described across Ezekiel 42:16-20?
options: 500 reeds by 500 reeds with a wall round about
100 cubits by 50 cubits with no walls
300 reeds by 400 reeds with gates only on the east
questions.correctAnswer: 500 reeds by 500 reeds with a wall round about
questions.explanation: Verses 16 through 20 describe the temple area as having four sides each measuring 500 reeds and a wall round about making a separation between sanctuary and profane place.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 42:9, the entry to the chambers is from the west side of the utter court.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:9 states the entry to the chambers is on the east side from the utter court, not the west side.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 42:4, what is the width of the walk before the chambers?
questions.correctAnswer: 10 cubits
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:4 specifies a walk of ten cubits breadth inward before the chambers.

questions.question: The structure of the chambers described as galleries in three stories without pillars (Ezekiel 42:6) can be seen as what kind of architectural typology in ancient Near Eastern temple design?
options: A typology emphasizing vertical elevation and separation
A design for maximizing open courtyards
A typology reflecting agricultural storage facilities
A design for royal audience halls
questions.correctAnswer: A typology emphasizing vertical elevation and separation
questions.explanation: The three-story galleries without pillars, leading to a more straitened but elevated structure, typify vertical elevation and separation which is common in temple architectures emphasizing holiness and hierarchy.

questions.question: How does the detailed measurement of the temple area in Ezekiel 42:15-20 reflect the theme of holiness and separation found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It emphasizes the strict division between holy and profane, as seen also in Exodus 29
It shows the temple is accessible to all without restriction
It reflects the building style of pagan temples
It suggests a lack of concern for ritual purity
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the strict division between holy and profane, as seen also in Exodus 29
questions.explanation: The measurements and the wall round about in Ezekiel 42:20 symbolize the separation between the sanctuary and the profane, a theme also emphasized in Exodus, highlighting holiness and purity.

questions.question: What does the term 'most holy things' in Ezekiel 42:13 indicate about the priestly duties and the sacred space, in relation to Levitical laws?
options: It refers to items reserved strictly for priests under holiness codes in Leviticus
It means common food for all Israelites
It denotes weapons used in temple defense
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to items reserved strictly for priests under holiness codes in Leviticus
questions.explanation: The phrase 'most holy things' in Ezekiel 42:13 aligns with Levitical laws that designate certain offerings and items as holy, reserved only for priests, emphasizing ritual purity and sanctity.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 42 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 42 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:13, what is the primary purpose of the north and south chambers before the separate place?
options: They are holy chambers for priests to eat the most holy things
They are storage rooms for temple treasures
They serve as living quarters for the Levites
They are common areas for worshippers to gather
questions.correctAnswer: They are holy chambers for priests to eat the most holy things
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 states that these chambers are holy places where priests eat the most holy things, which aligns with the sanctity required for priestly duties (cf. Leviticus 10:12-13; Numbers 18:8-9; Hebrews 7:26-27; 1 Corinthians 9:13-14).

questions.question: What measurement is repeatedly given for the sides of the area measured around the gate facing east in Ezekiel 42?
questions.correctAnswer: Five hundred reeds
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:16-19 details that each side of the measured area is five hundred reeds, symbolizing completeness and separation between holy and profane (cf. Exodus 27:18; 1 Kings 6:2; Revelation 21:16; Ezekiel 40:5).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 42:14 indicate about the garments priests wear when moving from the holy chambers to the outer court?
options: They must leave their holy garments and put on other garments
They can wear the same garments throughout
They remove all garments and minister naked
They wear special garments only in the outer court
questions.correctAnswer: They must leave their holy garments and put on other garments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:14 instructs priests to leave their garments in the holy place and change before approaching things for the people, emphasizing the holiness and separation in priestly ministry (cf. Exodus 28:41; Leviticus 6:10; Hebrews 7:26; 1 Timothy 2:5).

questions.question: How many stories did the galleries have that were over against the pavement of the utter court according to Ezekiel 42:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Three stories
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:3 describes galleries built in three stories opposite the pavement, indicating a structured architectural design for temple chambers (cf. 2 Chronicles 4:5; Ezekiel 40:22; Solomon’s temple structure in 1 Kings 6).

questions.question: What does the wall around the four sides measured by the reed symbolize in Ezekiel 42:20?
options: Separation between the sanctuary and the profane place
The boundary of the city of Jerusalem
A barrier for the Levites only
questions.correctAnswer: Separation between the sanctuary and the profane place
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:20 explicitly states the wall’s purpose is to separate the sanctuary from the profane, highlighting God's holiness and the need for separation between holy and common (cf. Exodus 19:10-12; Leviticus 10:3; Hebrews 12:14; 1 Peter 1:15-16).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The chambers were in the thickness of the wall of the court toward the ___, over against the separate place (Ezekiel 42:10).
questions.correctAnswer: East
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:10 specifies the chambers are located in the thickness of the wall toward the east, reflecting the orientation of the temple complex facing east as a symbol of divine presence (cf. Ezekiel 40:6; Matthew 24:27; Luke 1:78; Revelation 21:12).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:4, what was the breadth of the walk before the chambers inward?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten cubits
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:4 mentions a walk of ten cubits breadth inward before the chambers, indicating a measured and orderly space for movement, consistent with temple design principles (cf. Ezekiel 40:28; 1 Kings 6:5; Exodus 26:3; Hebrews 9:2).

questions.question: Why were the upper chambers described as shorter in Ezekiel 42:5?
options: Because the galleries were higher than the lower and middle chambers
Because the upper chambers were reserved for common people
Because they were incomplete at the time
Because they were outside the temple complex
questions.correctAnswer: Because the galleries were higher than the lower and middle chambers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:5 explains the upper chambers were shorter since the galleries were higher, highlighting the temple’s architectural complexity and hierarchy of sacred spaces (cf. Ezekiel 40:22-23; 1 Kings 6:6-7; Psalm 48:12; Hebrews 9:2).

questions.question: What specific offerings were to be laid in the holy chambers according to Ezekiel 42:13?
options: Most holy things, meat offering, sin offering, and trespass offering
questions.correctAnswer: Most holy things, meat offering, sin offering, and trespass offering
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13 lists these offerings as kept in the holy chambers, underscoring the sanctity of the place and the priestly handling of atonement and dedication offerings (cf. Leviticus 7:1-21; Hebrews 9:12-14; Leviticus 4; Numbers 18:10-11).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 42:6, why was the building more straitened than the lower and middlemost chambers from the ground?
options: Because the upper stories lacked pillars like those of the courts
Because it was outside the temple walls
questions.correctAnswer: Because the upper stories lacked pillars like those of the courts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:6 explains the lack of pillars in upper stories caused the building to be more narrow, showing the structural design and symbolism of the temple’s holy architecture (cf. 1 Kings 7:15-22; Ezekiel 40:26; Hebrews 9:2-3; Exodus 26:37).

questions.question: What direction did the way before the chambers face according to Ezekiel 42:4 and 42:12?
questions.correctAnswer: North
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:4 and 42:12 specify the doors and ways of the chambers faced north, emphasizing the ordered orientation of the temple complex which reflects divine order (cf. Ezekiel 40:6; Psalm 48:1; 1 Kings 6:4; Revelation 7:1).

questions.question: What feature did the chambers share on the east side as described in Ezekiel 42:9?
options: An entry from the utter court
A secret passage to the holy place
questions.correctAnswer: An entry from the utter court
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:9 notes the chambers had an entry on the east side from the utter court, indicating controlled access related to priestly functions and worship (cf. Ezekiel 40:27; Exodus 27:13-16; Leviticus 16:3; Hebrews 9:6).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 42:1, where was the prophet brought before entering the chambers?
options: Into the utter court toward the north
Into the inner court toward the south
Into the outer gate facing west
questions.correctAnswer: Into the utter court toward the north
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:1 describes the prophet being brought into the utter court toward the north, showing the temple’s spatial progression and the symbolism of entering holy space (cf. Ezekiel 40:5; Exodus 27:13; Hebrews 9:2; Psalm 24:3-4).

questions.question: What is the significance of the precise measurements given for the temple chambers and courts in Ezekiel 42?
options: They symbolize God's order and holiness in worship space
They are arbitrary and have no symbolic meaning
They indicate a defensive fortress design
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize God's order and holiness in worship space
questions.explanation: The detailed measurements in Ezekiel 42 emphasize divine order and separation of holy and profane, consistent with biblical theology of God's holiness (cf. Exodus 25:9; 1 Kings 6:2-20; Hebrews 9:1-5; Leviticus 19:2).

questions.question: How does the description of the chambers in Ezekiel 42 relate to the doctrine of priestly mediation?
options: They serve as places where priests handle holy offerings and change garments, emphasizing mediation
They are merely storage rooms with no priestly function
They are places where laypeople worship directly
They are symbolic of God's omnipresence
questions.correctAnswer: They serve as places where priests handle holy offerings and change garments, emphasizing mediation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 42:13-14 highlights the chambers as holy spaces for priests to manage offerings and garments, reflecting the biblical role of priests mediating between God and people (cf. Hebrews 7:23-27; Leviticus 16; 1 Timothy 2:5; Exodus 28:41).
